title: Quiz: FQE June 2023 - Community Health
description: Final Qualifying Examination for Diploma in Clinical Medicine & Surgery - Community Health (June 2023)

questions.question: You are invited to give a health talk on child weaning. Which of the following would form part of your information?

options.text: It is advisable to mix weaning foods with high energy concentration into the basic staple food
Your children should be fed more than four times a day
Breast feeding should be stopped during weaning to avoid food interactions

questions.explanation: Basic staples (like maize porridge) are bulky but low in energy. Enriching them with oil, milk, or groundnuts (high energy/protein) is essential for the growing child. Breastfeeding should continue up to 2 years.
questions.hint: Think about energy density versus bulk in traditional porridge.

questions.question: A Clinical Officer who does blood pressure screening and related health education is conducting activities in the level of:
questions.explanation: Secondary Prevention involves early diagnosis and treatment (Screening). Primary Prevention prevents disease onset (Immunization). Tertiary reduces disability.
questions.hint: Screening aims to find disease that is already present but asymptomatic.

questions.question: The habitual presence of a disease or infections agent with a given geographical area is:
questions.explanation: Endemic refers to the constant presence or usual prevalence of a disease within a geographic area.
questions.hint: It is 'native' or constantly 'in' the population.

questions.question: The health care activities that are representing primary prevention include:

options.text: Getting immunized and practicing safe sex
Starting an exercise and height reduction program

questions.explanation: Primary prevention aims to prevent the disease from occurring. Immunization (Specific Protection) and Safe Sex (preventing STI transmission) are classic examples.
questions.hint: Which option prevents the disease from ever entering the body?

questions.question: Determine the correct response regarding health education:

options.text: Helps attain their health through the nurses' role efforts
Is a fast and mushroom like process
Is a slow and continuous process

questions.explanation: Health education aims at changing behavior, which takes time. It is not an overnight event but a continuous process of learning and adaptation.
questions.hint: Behavior change does not happen overnight.

questions.question: For primary health care to improve health, people must first have:
questions.explanation: Meeting basic needs (Food, Shelter, Water, Security) is fundamental before medical services can effectively improve overall health status (Maslow's hierarchy).
questions.hint: Think about the most fundamental requirements for life.

questions.question: Understanding of health determination is essential for:

options.text: Primary health care interventions and assessment
Effective programs to enable people to maintain good health
Organization of health services in regions or cities

questions.explanation: Determinants of health (Social, Economic, Environmental) are the core focus of PHC. Understanding them allows for effective intervention planning.
questions.hint: This relates to the core function of PHC planning.

questions.question: Choose the vitamin deficiency commonly found in Chronic alcoholics:
questions.explanation: Chronic alcoholism leads to Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency, which can cause Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.
questions.hint: This vitamin is Thiamine.

questions.question: Determine the vitamin with anticancer properties:
questions.explanation: Vitamins A (Retinoids), C, and E are antioxidants helping prevent cell damage. Vitamin A helps in cell differentiation.
questions.hint: This vitamin is also essential for vision.

questions.question: Which of the following is a result of high exposure of radiation?
questions.explanation: High doses of radiation damage rapidly dividing cells. Bone marrow suppression leads to a rapid drop in white blood cells (Leukopenia).
questions.hint: It affects the immune system cells in the bone marrow.

questions.question: Choose the water-washed disease in the following responses:
questions.explanation: Water-washed diseases (like Scabies and Trachoma) are caused by insufficient water for personal hygiene. Cholera/Typhoid are Water-borne.
questions.hint: This disease relates to skin hygiene.

questions.question: Select the water-borne disease group:

options.text: Cholera, trachoma, schistosomiasis and yellow fever
Cholera, typhoid, amoebic and bacillary dysentery
Scabies, trachoma, schistosomiasis and yellow fever

questions.explanation: Option B consists entirely of diseases transmitted through ingestion of contaminated water (fecal-oral route).
questions.hint: All diseases in the correct option affect the gastrointestinal tract.

questions.question: The most appropriate age for implementation of primordial measures for prevention of cervical cancer is:
questions.explanation: 9-14 years is the target age for the HPV vaccine (primary prevention) before sexual debut.
questions.hint: This is the target age for the HPV vaccine.

questions.question: Determine the correct response that implies communicable diseases:

options.text: Host who can transmit the pathogens before showing symptoms are described as convalescent carriers
Host who can transmit the pathogen beyond the period of illness are described as incubating carriers
The line between the onset and end of communicability is described as the latent period
The period of communicability is the state where the host is infectious and shedding pathogens into the environment

questions.explanation: Period of communicability is the time during which an infectious agent may be transferred from an infected person to another.
questions.hint: It is the time when you can pass the disease to others.

questions.question: Select the appropriate characteristic of non-communicable disease:
questions.explanation: NCDs typically have a long latency period (time between exposure to risk factors and disease onset) and complex/multifactorial etiology.
questions.hint: They take a long time to develop and have complex causes.

questions.question: Categorize zoonotic diseases from responses below:

options.text: Scabies, pediculosis, chicken pox and herpes

questions.explanation: All listed in the correct option are zoonoses: Rabies (Dogs), Plague (Rodents), Salmonellosis (Poultry), Brucellosis (Cattle).
questions.hint: Ensure every disease in the list comes from animals.

questions.question: Mechanisms of disease transmission in communicable disease include:

options.text: Droplet, trans placental and physical contact
Vector borne, mechanical transfer and vehicle borne

questions.explanation: Option D lists three distinct types (Vector, Mechanical [e.g. flies], Vehicle [water/food]).
questions.hint: Look for the option that includes transmission by insects and inanimate objects.

questions.question: The major cardiovascular disease is:
questions.explanation: Ischaemic heart disease and Hypertension are the top cardiovascular killers globally.
questions.hint: This condition involves high blood pressure.

questions.question: Determine advantage of the population strategy in disease prevention:
questions.explanation: The population strategy attempts to shift the whole distribution of exposure and is often 'Behaviorally appropriate' because it establishes new social norms.
questions.hint: It makes healthy behavior the 'norm' for everyone.

questions.question: Select factors that influence the severity of post-crash outcomes in road traffic accidents in Kenya:

options.text: Inappropriate pre-hospital care, delayed rescue and demographic factors
Inappropriate pre-hospital care, delayed rescue and inappropriate care at emergency centers
Inappropriate pre-hospital care, delayed rescue and presence of road side objects
Inappropriate pre-hospital care, fatigue and road designs

questions.explanation: Post-crash outcomes depend on what happens *after* the crash: Response time, First Aid, and Hospital care.
questions.hint: Focus on what happens *after* the accident occurs.

questions.question: Choose the correct statement regarding hospital waste management:

options.text: Clinical waste such as used gloves are stored in yellow jerry cans
Clinical waste such as used needles are stored in black line bags
General waste including food remains are stored in safety boxes
Sharp and clinical waste such as syringes are stored in safety box

questions.explanation: Sharps (needles, syringes, blades) must always be disposed of in puncture-proof Safety Boxes.
questions.hint: Needles need puncture-proof containers.

questions.question: Which of the following is a barrier method of birth control?
questions.explanation: The Diaphragm and Condom are barrier methods that physically prevent sperm from meeting the egg.
questions.hint: It creates a physical wall/barrier.

questions.question: Identify the response which does NOT correspond to the roles of a community health worker:

options.text: Referral of patients from community level to health centers

questions.explanation: CHWs are lay workers trained in health promotion and basic curative care. They do not perform surgeries.
questions.hint: CHWs perform basic tasks, not complex medical procedures.

questions.question: Which of the following is the biological importance of the housefly?

options.text: They help in the transmission of diseases

questions.explanation: Medical 'importance' refers to their role as mechanical vectors for diseases like Cholera and Typhoid.
questions.hint: Think about why they are a health concern.

questions.question: Solid waste arising from the preparation, cooking and consumption of food is referred to as:
questions.explanation: Garbage specifically refers to putrescible (biodegradable) waste like food scraps. Rubbish is non-putrescible.
questions.hint: This type of waste rots and smells.

questions.question: Select the appropriate activity in child growth monitoring:

options.text: Measurement of mid upper arm circumference

questions.explanation: Growth monitoring typically involves measuring anthropometrics like Weight or MUAC (for acute malnutrition).
questions.hint: This measures nutritional status using the arm.

questions.question: Identify the correct response regarding herd immunity:

options.text: Is conferred when a high percentage of the population is vaccinated
Is conferred when a high percentage and population had acquired passive immunity
Gives a high level of individual immunity thus is alternative of getting vaccinated
Offers protection against all other vaccine preventable diseases

questions.explanation: Herd immunity occurs when a large proportion of a community becomes immune, protecting the unvaccinated.
questions.hint: It protects the 'herd' because most people are immune.

questions.question: Which of the following strategies can be used to reduce alcohol abuse?

options.text: Identify and publicly condemn problem drinkers
Make water and soft drinks easily available
Increase the price of illicit liquor and reduce price of beer

questions.explanation: Enforcement of drunk-driving laws is a WHO 'Best Buy' strategy for reducing alcohol-related harm.
questions.hint: This involves the police and road safety.

questions.question: A study where researcher look forward as he records the finding with time is termed as:
questions.explanation: A study that looks forward in time is Prospective. A Cohort study is typically prospective.
questions.hint: The term means 'looking forward'.

questions.question: Identify the response which is NOT a medical legal issue:
questions.explanation: Post-mortems are standard pathological/legal procedures. The other options involve complex ethical/legal dilemmas or rights violations.
questions.hint: Which one is a routine procedure ordered by law?

questions.question: Which among the following does NOT correspond to comprehensive disaster preparedness strategy?
questions.explanation: Hazard/Risk Assessment is typically part of the Mitigation or foundational phase, while Preparedness (Drills, Resources) happens after risks are known.
questions.hint: This is usually done BEFORE planning the response, in the mitigation/assessment phase.

questions.question: Determine natural disaster from the responses below:

options.text: Cholera outbreaks, bioterrorism, Ozone layer depletion

questions.explanation: Option C contains mostly natural events (Weather/Climate). The others mix in man-made disasters (Terrorism, Accidents).
questions.hint: Look for the group with NO man-made events.

questions.question: If all couples in the nation decide to bear one child, what is the probable outcome in the population?

options.text: Continue to grow for at least 60-70 years then stop

questions.explanation: Due to 'Population Momentum', a population with a large young base continues to grow for decades even if fertility drops below replacement.
questions.hint: Think about 'Population Momentum'.

questions.question: Age structure of the population is determined by:
questions.explanation: Fertility (Birth Rate) is the primary determinant of age structure. High fertility creates a young population (broad base).
questions.hint: Which factor adds new young people to the bottom of the pyramid?

questions.question: Determine protective measures employed to prevent contamination of water in a shallow well:
questions.explanation: Installing a hand pump allows the well to be sealed (covered), preventing contaminants from entering via buckets/ropes or runoff.
questions.hint: This prevents dirt from entering the well physically.

questions.question: Determine steps in medical waste disposal you would impose as a clinician:

options.text: Disposal, treatment, storage, transportation and segregation
Storing, sorting, transportation, treatment and disposal
Sorting, storage, transportation, disposal and segregation
Segregation, sorting, treatment, storage, transportation and disposal

questions.explanation: The most critical first step at the point of generation is Segregation.
questions.hint: You must separate the waste FIRST.

questions.question: Identify the correct response regarding importance of fiber in diet:

options.text: Slows digestion so that one does not feel hungry
Reduces absorption of iron preventing haemosiderosis
Makes food lighter for easy absorption

questions.explanation: Fiber adds bulk and slows gastric emptying, promoting satiety (feeling full), which helps prevent obesity.
questions.hint: It makes you feel full longer.

questions.question: Choose the characteristic of housing which is inappropriate for communicable disease prevention:
questions.explanation: Dampness promotes mold growth and respiratory infections. It is a negative factor.
questions.hint: Which one promotes mold and bacteria?

questions.question: Which age cohort is considered most susceptible to harmful products in the home?
questions.explanation: Young children (exploratory nature) and the elderly (poor vision, confusion) are most at risk of accidental poisoning or injury.
questions.hint: The very young and the very old.

questions.question: Calculate the modal value of this data: 2.5, 6, 7.2, 8, 3, 2.5, 3, 6, 8, 3.
questions.explanation: The number 3 appears most frequently (3 times). 2.5, 6, and 8 appear 2 times each.
questions.hint: The Mode is the number that appears the most.

questions.question: Determine the factors that influence development of a disease (Epidemiological Triad):
questions.explanation: The Epidemiological Triad consists of Agent, Host, and Environment.
questions.hint: Think of the triangle: Who gets sick, what makes them sick, and where.

questions.question: Compile characteristics of non-communicable diseases (NCDs):
questions.explanation: NCDs have complex causes, take a long time to develop, and last a long time. They are not contagious.
questions.hint: They are chronic and not infectious.

questions.question: What are the factors that determine health care delivery?
questions.explanation: The 5 As: Availability, Accessibility, Affordability, Acceptability, Adequacy.
questions.hint: Think of the 5 'A's.

questions.question: Arrange the links in the Chain of Infection in the correct logical sequence:
questions.explanation: The germ leaves the reservoir, travels, enters the new host.
questions.hint: Start with the bug itself, then where it lives.

questions.question: Select valid sources of epidemiological data:
questions.explanation: Standard sources include Census, Vital stats, Hospital records, and Surveys.
questions.hint: Official records and national surveys.

questions.question: Recommend the characteristics of a GOOD screening test:
questions.explanation: A good test must be Accurate, Repeatable, Cheap, Safe, and Accepted by people.
questions.hint: It should be cheap, accurate, and not hurt.

questions.question: As a clinician, how would you make quality primary health care accessible and affordable?
questions.explanation: Strategies include community involvement, taking services to people (outreach), and reducing costs (insurance/subsidies).
questions.hint: Think about removing barriers.

questions.question: Elaborate on the causes of food spoilage:
questions.explanation: Spoilage is caused by microbes, enzymes, pests, physical damage, and environmental factors like heat.
questions.hint: What makes food rot?

questions.question: Scenario: You are leading a team managing a CHOLERA outbreak (Rice water stool). Select the correct approaches you would use:

richContent.content: Situation: Sudden onset diarrhea and vomiting in a rural facility. Diagnosis: Suspected Cholera.

options.text: Collect stool samples (rectal swabs) for lab confirmation
Set up an isolation ward / Cholera Treatment Centre (CTC)
Chlorinate water sources and distribute water treatment tabs
Advise community to eat raw vegetables
Wait for lab results before treating patients

questions.explanation: Key steps: Verification, Isolation, Case Management (Rehydration), WASH (Chlorination), and Education. Never delay treatment for lab results.
questions.hint: Select the actions that save lives and stop the spread.
